channel.title: What does this mean?
channel.description:
So... this isn't so much directly a help thread as it is me just being curious but erm i found this in the server I'm working on could someone explain to me what it means?
[Code]int toWrite = !b && tile != null ? 5 : 0;[/Code]
I'm not asking about what the code goes to I know that I'm asking about this part specifically...
[Code]!b[/Code]
And what's confusing me is how/why its being used with a int and what effect it has.
Oh b is a boolean btw.
Edit: Yes, thank you I'm aware but why is it being used in the context of a integer and how does that effect the outcome?
Edit: Nvm tested this...
[Code] boolean q = true; boolean b = false; int f = !b && q ? 1 : 0; [/Code]
b must be false for q to ever be 1.

item.title: What does this mean?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

The part you’re asking about specifically is checking if “b” is false.

Your code translates into:

int toWrite = 0; if(b == false && tile != null) toWrite = 5; else toWrite = 0;

Read full topic

item.title: What does this mean?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

whoever wrote that code should be shot

Read full topic

item.title: What does this mean?
item.dc:creator: @Paragon Paragon
item.description:
@Paragon wrote:

Another way to look at that is

if(!b && tile != null)
     toWrite = 5;
else
     toWrite = 0;

!b means b == false

Edit: You have the wrong idea for

[code]boolean q = true; boolean b = false; int f = !b && q ? 1 : 0;[/code]

b must be false for q to ever be 1.

B must be false and q must be true for f to ever be 1.

Read full topic

So… this isn’t so much directly a help thread as it is me just being curious but erm i found this in the server I’m working on could someone explain to me what it means?

int toWrite = !b && tile != null ? 5 : 0;

And what’s confusing me is how/why its being used with a int and what effect it has.

Edit: Yes, thank you I’m aware but why is it being used in the context of a integer and how does that effect the outcome?

Edit: Nvm tested this…

boolean q = true; boolean b = false; int f = !b && q ? 1 : 0;

b must be false for q to ever be 1.
